paragraphs.text:
%md
--
## Classification Modeling to Predict Target Customers using XGBoost
In this notebook, we  predict customers most likely to be positive responders to an Affinity Card loyalty program. High Affinity Card responders (target value = 1) are defined as those customers who when given a loyaly or affinity card hyper-respond i.e. they increae their purchasing higher than the Affinity Card program's offered discount percentage.  This notebook builds and applies classification xgboost models using the SH schema data. All processing occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation                             
###### [The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0](https://oss.oracle.com/licenses/upl/)
---

msg.data:
–

Classification Modeling to Predict Target Customers using XGBoost

In this notebook, we predict customers most likely to be positive responders to an Affinity Card loyalty program. High Affinity Card responders (target value = 1) are defined as those customers who when given a loyaly or affinity card hyper-respond i.e. they increae their purchasing higher than the Affinity Card program's offered discount percentage. This notebook builds and applies classification xgboost models using the SH schema data. All processing occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Graph HOUSEHOLD_SIZE grouped by AFFINITY_CARD responders
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Create a Bar chart of HOUSEHOLD_SIZE (Keys), AFFINITY_CARD (Groups), NUM_CUSTOMERS (SUM) (Values)

SELECT COUNT(CUST_ID) AS NUM_CUSTOMERS, HOUSEHOLD_SIZE, AFFINITY_CARD 
FROM   SH.SUPPLEMENTARY_DEMOGRAPHICS 
GROUP BY HOUSEHOLD_SIZE, AFFINITY_CARD;

paragraphs.title: Create view DEMOGRAPHICS4_V with desired columns for analysis
paragraphs.text:
%script

CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW DEMOGRAPHICS4_V 
  AS SELECT AFFINITY_CARD, BOOKKEEPING_APPLICATION,
            BULK_PACK_DISKETTES, CUST_ID, EDUCATION,
            FLAT_PANEL_MONITOR, HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE, 
            HOUSEHOLD_SIZE, OCCUPATION, OS_DOC_SET_KANJI,
            PRINTER_SUPPLIES, YRS_RESIDENCE, Y_BOX_GAMES
  FROM   SH.SUPPLEMENTARY_DEMOGRAPHICS;

msg.data:
View DEMOGRAPHICS4_V created.


---------------------------

paragraphs.title: Create train and test data sets (60/40) for model build and test

msg.data:
View TRAIN_DATA_CLAS created.


---------------------------

View TEST_DATA_CLAS created.


---------------------------

Examples of possible setting overrides for XGBoost

If the user does not override the default settings, then relevant settings are determined by the algorithm

A complete list of settings can be found in the Documentation link:

– Algorithm Settings: XGBoost

– Switch between booster - gblinear, gbtree, dart

 By default the system uses the gbtree. The parameters are similar for gbtree and dart, but has more difference comparing to gblinear

v_setlst('booster') := 'gblinear';
v_setlst('booster') := 'gbtree';
v_setlst('booster') := 'dart';

– regularization parameters for all boosters

v_setlst('alpha')     := '0.1';
v_setlst('eta')       := '0.3';
v_setlst('lambda')    := '0.3';

– regularization parameters for tree based boosters: gbtree, dart

v_setlst('gamma')           := '0.1';
v_setlst('max_delta_step')  := '0.1';
v_setlst('max_depth')       := '6';
v_setlst('max_leaves')      := '10';
v_setlst('min_child_weight'):= '1';

– subsampling methods for tree based boosters: gbtree, dart

v_setlst('colsample_bylevel') := '1';
v_setlst('colsample_bynode')  := '1';
v_setlst('colsample_bytree')  := '1';

– Num of iteration rounds

v_setlst('num_round') := '100';

– For binary classification tasks, the objective is

v_setlst('objective') := 'binary:logistic';

paragraphs.title: View model's cumulative gains (lift) chart
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Create a Line chart of QUANTILE_NUMBER (Keys), GAIN_CUMULATIVE(SUM) (Values); No Groups
-- Hint: Try changing this to Bar chart from the below visual settings

SELECT QUANTILE_NUMBER, GAIN_CUMULATIVE FROM LIFT_TABLE;

paragraphs.title: Display all customers with likelihood > 50% to be AFFINITY_CARD responders
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT   CUST_ID, PREDICTION PRED, ROUND(PROBABILITY,3) PROB, ROUND(COST,2) COST 
FROM     APPLY_RESULT WHERE PREDICTION = 1 AND PROBABILITY > 0.5 
ORDER BY PROBABILITY DESC FETCH FIRST 10 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.title: Interactively show customer probability to be AFFINITY_CARD responders
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT A.*, B.* 
FROM   APPLY_RESULT A, TEST_DATA_CLAS B 
WHERE  PREDICTION = ${PREDICTION='1','1'|'0'} AND A.CUST_ID = B.CUST_ID FETCH FIRST 10 ROWS ONLY;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Create interactive pie chart of EDUCATION for likely or unlikely AFFINITY_CARD responders
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Graph Pie chart of EDUCATION (Keys), CUST_ID (COUNT) (Values);  No Groups
-- Hint: Try changing the graph type to a Bar chart

SELECT A.*, B.* 
FROM   APPLY_RESULT A, TEST_DATA_CLAS B 
WHERE  PREDICTION = ${PREDICTION='1','1'|'0'} AND A.CUST_ID = B.CUST_ID
FETCH FIRST 10 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.title: Use SQL query to dynamically score and select customers with >=50% probability of being AFFINITY_CARD responders
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT * 
FROM (SELECT CUST_ID, 
    PREDICTION_PROBABILITY(XGBOOST_CLASS_MODEL, '1' USING A.*) PROBABILITY
FROM TEST_DATA_CLAS A)
WHERE PROBABILITY > 0.5 
FETCH FIRST 10 ROWS ONLY;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Apply the model to a single new record
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Predict the probability of being a high AFFINITY_CARD responder (1) 
-- by providing specific attribute values for a customer.

SELECT ROUND(PREDICTION_PROBABILITY(XGBOOST_CLASS_MODEL, '1' USING 
    '3' AS HOUSEHOLD_SIZE, 
     5 AS YRS_RESIDENCE, 
     1 AS Y_BOX_GAMES),3) PROBABILITY_AFFINITY_CARD_RESPONDER
FROM DUAL;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
PROBABILITY_AFFINITY_CARD_RESPONDER
0.208

paragraphs.title: Get prediction details
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT CUST_ID,
    round(PREDICTION_YRS_RES,3) PRED_YRS_RES,
    RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute1",17,100)),'rank="1"/>') FIRST_ATTRIBUTE,
    RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute2",17,100)),'rank="2"/>') SECOND_ATTRIBUTE,
    RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute3",17,100)),'rank="3"/>') THIRD_ATTRIBUTE
FROM (SELECT CUST_ID,
     PREDICTION(XGBOOST_CLASS_MODEL USING *) PREDICTION_YRS_RES,
     PREDICTION_DETAILS(XGBOOST_CLASS_MODEL USING *) PD
    FROM TRAIN_DATA_CLAS
    WHERE CUST_ID < 100025
    ORDER BY CUST_ID) OUT,
    XMLTABLE('/Details'
    PASSING OUT.PD
    COLUMNS 
    "Attribute1" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[1]',
    "Attribute2" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[2]',
    "Attribute3" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[3]') 
    OUTPRED

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Create Classification Model using Settings Table

The settings table is an alternative way to specify algorithm settings to build the model. We first drop the settings table, create it, and then populate it with settings before building the model.

msg.data:
Create Classification Model using Settings Table

The settings table is an alternative way to specify algorithm settings to build the model. We first drop the settings table, create it, and then populate it with settings before building the model.
